body:
What exactly do you mean by that? What are you trying to support?

Are we talking about touchscreen usage? Or is this a touchpad thing?
I suspect to support this well alacritty would need to also support smooth scrolling.

While I understand the idea behind that (it would certainly "feel" better), I don't think it's **necessary** for it to work.

We should have a 'distance' from origin and can just verify based on that by how many lines we should offset the viewport. It would be jerky, sure, but it should work and be usable I'd assume. At least more usable than no support at all.
Yes please! Smooth scrolling would be a nice feel good and make some stuff a lot more intuitive.

issue.title: Gnome 40 Wayland, can't interact with CSD with my fingers
issue.body:
GNOME 40 Wayland, can't neither drag the window by the titlebar nor close it with a finger. Mouse works fine.
I'm aware you largely don't care about Gnome users, but this issue goes slightly beyond just look-and-feel.

### System

OS: Linux, NixOS 21.05
Version: alacritty 0.8.0
Linux/BSD: Gnome 40 Wayland

body:
Merging in the observation from #5204.

GNOME 40.
I can select text with touchscreen and stylus, which I find adequate basic functionality. I don't miss scrolling one bit, but CSD is problematic. I can't drag the window by the title with neither my fingers nor my stylus. Titlebar buttons don't react to them either.

It looks like PR #4346 was a bit of a flop. It seems to me that, as Dreomite suggests at the bottom of that thread, a good path forward is a much less complex patch providing only minimal functionality.

For my own use, I desperately want a tap on the touchscreen to be translated to a click. (This way I can switch between vim/tmux windows easily.) A distant second is scrolling. The things that were controversial in the last attempt --- selection, what happens when the finger moves horizontally, what multiple fingers do, what a hold means --- I really don't care about.

So: @chrisduerr, how would you feel, in principle, about a very minimal patch just to get "tap = click" functional? Would such an attempt be welcome, or would you rather have proper touchscreen support in one go? If you're okay with a small change that leaves the hard work undone and the hard decisions unmade, I'll try for it.
I think a patch to just add support for clicking on touchscreens should be fairly uncontroversial.

issue.title: Touch-to-click
issue.body:
This is a baby step towards touch support: tapping will click, but no other touch functionality is available. It does most of what *I* want, but of course I can't vouch for anyone else...

Because of the simplicity of this change, there are a few strange behaviors. None of them seem to be "biting" or potentially harmful, but here's the ones I know of:

- The message bar is not handled correctly. If you tap on the message bar, that gets interpreted as a click behind the message bar.
- Dragging is not detected. That doesn't just mean you can't scroll; it also means that if you drag, it interprets it as a click at the last place your finger was.
- Multitouch is totally ignored. If you put one finger down, then another, then lift the first, it interprets that as a "click". When you lift the second, that's another "click".

Note (as mentioned in the commits) that this code essentially contains a workaround for winit issue 1996. The main part of that workaround is that it necessitates keeping track of a `TouchState` object --- that'll be necessary eventually anyway, so I don't feel guilty.

I have added no tests, expecting that touch behavior will change substantially in the future, and those tests would need to be immediately re-written. Tests have been modified only to keep them compiling (necessary cuz of the additional variable tracking TouchState).

Finally, a question: to detect the difference between a drag (to be ignored, for now) and a tap, it's necessary to have some sort of threshold, probably in distance moved. Is this worthy of adding a configuration option to alacritty.yml? I think the only real alternative is a hidden constant somewhere.

Thanks,
Scott
